greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of the prime zeta modulo function at 2 for primes of the form 4k+3.
link: Jean-François Alcover, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..999
P. Flajolet and I. Vardi, Zeta Function Expansions of Classical Constants, Unpublished manuscript. 1996.
X. Gourdon and P. Sebah, Some Constants from Number theory.
R. J. Mathar, Table of Dirichlet L-series and prime zeta modulo functions for small moduli, arXiv:1008.2547 [math.NT], 2010-2015, section 3.2 constant P(m=4,n=3,s=2).
formula: where b(x)=(1-2^(-x))*zeta(x)/L(x) and L(x) is the Dirichlet Beta function.
mathematica: PrimeZeta43[s_, nmax_] := PrimeZeta43[s, nmax] = (1/2) Sum[(MoebiusMu[2n + 1] ((4n + 2) Log[2] + Log[((-1 + 2^(4n + 2)) Zeta[4n + 2])/(Zeta[4 n + 2, 1/4] - Zeta[4n + 2, 3/4])]))/(2n + 1), {n, 0, nmax}] // N[#, digits+5]&;
While[Abs[PrimeZeta43[2, nmax] - PrimeZeta43[2, nmax - dnmax]] > 10^-(digits+5), Print["nmax = ", nmax]; nmax += dnmax];
RealDigits[PrimeZeta43[2], 10, digits][[1]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 21 2011, updated May 06 2021 *)
xref: Cf. A086032 (analog for primes 4k+1), A085548 (PrimeZeta(2)), A002145.
results.author: Antonio G. Astudillo (afg_astudillo(AT)lycos.com), Jul 06 2003
